My wife has a lot of cosmetic brushes. From time to time she has to wash and dry them. This holder helps in this task as it keeps the brushes organized in vertical position with the tip pointing down. Plenty of holes of different diameter for smaller and larger brushes' sizes.

I made it some time ago and I don't remember the printer settings. Sorry for that.
Some pieces are quite large and need to be flat so ensure good adherence to the printing bed.

Extra materials:

  • some glue
  • EVA foam
  • a cutter
  • a pencil

Steps:
1) Print the parts.
2) Put the foam on a table. Put one of the part with the holes over the foam.
3) With a pencil draw all the edges and holes of the part in the foam.
4) Remove the printed part and cut off a rectangle of foam. It should be the same size as the printed part.
5) Cut 3 inner crossing lines connecting the opposite vertices of each hexagon in the foam.
6) Make a nice sandwich with the two printed parts and the foam in the middle. Glue it all together.
7) Enjoy.

Fun little project to neatly hold a dozen K-cups. Guaranteed to bring smiles to the faces of your family and friends. I'm not sure why, but a frog seemed like the perfect topper for this K-cup tree. Credit for the excellent frog goes to SSW http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:189563. I printed the parts in ABS. I had to use hair spray on the platen to keep the parts from lifting at the edges. Of course, then they were a challenge to remove, but patience and care prevailed. Enjoy! <Update 5-8-14> Added a version of the topper without the frog so you can customize your own top!

Material: ABS (MakerBot Rep 2X)
Settings: MakerBot 2X default...
Shells: 2
Infill: 5-10%
Prep: Acetone clean platen, hairspray (Tresemme25 from WalMart did the trick) My kapton is old so I needed the hairspray to prevent lifting of the large radius parts.
Supports: nope
Other: I paused printing just at start of top layer of the rings to wipe the grunge off of the extruder that way I did not end up with ugly black blobs embedded in the surface.
Also, the bottom of the stopper splays out a bit from the hot platen so you will need to lightly sand the around the bottom edge to get the stopper to fit into the stand.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus Template for Simplify3D

description.text:
Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus Template for Simplify3D

I have not found a suitable template so i have made myself one. The template I have made is for Simplify3D but i have read somewhere that it also works with other slicers.

The package contains three different versions.

Version 1 is for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus
Version 2 is for rebrands like Monoprice Maker Select Plus and Cocoon CreateTouch
Version 3 can be used with all Duplicator i3 V.2.1 and rebranded models.

Simplify3D template Installation:

  1. Copy the stl file (Wanhao_Duplicator_i3_Plus_template_full.stl) to the following folder:
        C: \ Users \ USERNAME \ AppData \ Local \ Simplify3D \ S3D software

  2. Start Simplify3D and export your FFF profile to the desktop (File-> Export FFF profile)

  3. Open the profile with an editor e.g:Notepad and search for the following entries ....

    overridePrinterModels>0</overridePrinterModels
    printerModelsOverride></printerModelsOverride

.....change the upper value from 0 to 1 and in the second line enter the name of the template. like below

   overridePrinterModels>1</overridePrinterModels
   printerModelsOverride>TEMPLATE NAME.STL</printerModelsOverride

If overridePrinterModels already is set to 1, you do not need to change this.

Save the FFF profile and import it back to Simpify3D
Restart Simplify3D

Tip:
If you think the template is not centered. Import the model to Simplify3D, change the position and Export the model (File->Export Models->Export Binary STL)

author: eried

description.text: Bead?

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
I dropped a chunk of concrete on my finger a while ago, which crushed it in a spectacularly painful way. I didn't want to go to a clinic just to be told to support it and avoid using the finger until it healed (there's not much you can do for a fingertip, even if it's broken). I had other splints on hand, but they all had a fatal flaw - you can't type with them due to their bulk. Clearly I needed a better solution.

Putting pressure on the tip of my finger caused the most pain, and I was massively behind on my paperwork. I needed to be able to type! So I designed this splint to move the pressure of typing to the next joint down, keeping pressure off the fingertip while also immobilizing it. Creating the first revision was painful, but once I had a rudimentary support the following iterations were much easier.

It's constructed with hulled circles and spheres, offset by a few millimeters to account for the ovoid shape of a finger. The angle between the first and second joint is customizable, as are the lengths and widths of each section. I found that the angle was extremely important, picking an angle that's as close as possible to your resting hand position makes adjusting to typing with it very quick. I've included the .STL for the one I used on my finger, but you'll likely need to tailor one to fit.

My original design was solid, but I realized after a few minutes that the lack of airflow made my finger get sweaty, uncomfortable, and caused the splint to slip off. So I added cutouts to keep the splint in place while still allowing the skin to breathe. Due to the orientation of the part when it's printed, the support beams are the weak point of the design. They have a nasty tendency to snap off when removing the part from the print bed, or when removing support material. I had good results without supports, and recommend trying that first.

I'm hoping not to need this design again, but if I were to revisit it I'd attempt to use a silicone layer or flexible filament in part of the tip. My main complaint was that the plastic on plastic contact had very little friction, causing my finger to slip off the keys a few times. This would be worse with a flat key profile such as on most laptops.

Disclaimer: This is not a medical device, I am not a doctor, and I am not advocating that you treat yourself or anyone else with this design. It worked very well for me, though. I got my paperwork done, and the finger healed up nicely after a few weeks.

title: 380mm Long Twin Jet Drive Work Boat

description.text:
Hi All

EDIT - 23/01/2018 - I have now also included a 3d printable basic hull. There is no jet drive cut out so you would need to print and cut out your own drive to fit. With the jet drive creator's permission I may also include a hull with the main body of the drive already incorporated.

Based on this fantastic Jet Drive design, I decided to build a little twin jet drive jet boat based on two of these drives printed at 50% and powered by two 370 type brushed motors.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1952400

This is very much a 'kit' and will require the builder to fabricate some parts, glue on sheeting or planking etc. I.e. it is an intermediate level kit.

PLEASE SEE DXF FILES IN 'THING FILES' FOR THE LASER CUTTING FILES FOR THE HULL, DECKS AND WINDOW GLASS.

Parts required will consist of:

Wood-
3mm Laser plywood
0.8mm Laser plywood
2mm Square balsa or softwood stringers

Plastic-
1.5mm Acrylic or similar sheet for windows

3d Printed parts-
2x the jet drive units liked above printed at 50%
Windows (still to be finished)
Door
Cabin roof
Adapter plates (2x - same file mirrored) to fill the gap between jet pump and hull

Hardware-
2x 300 sized (I used 370) brushed motors or equiv brushless
2mm stainless steel shaft
Suitable bushes for the jet pumps
Piano wire for linkages
Suitable Lipo cell (I used 2s 1300mah)
RX, ESC and Servo

A short video of the first test in the kids' pool!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GS-Wt-r6vhg

https://youtu.be/2CsqiXyh5hQ

title: RAM Mount for Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge (Improved)

description.text:
I needed a RAM Mount for my Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge. I found one here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1635388 but there were a few things about it that I felt could be improved:

  • Reduced the unnecessary height on the sides (top and bottom) of the back part.
  • Eliminated the weird booleans near the main clip.
  • Added a thumb tab which makes removal and mounting easier.
  • Added hex shapes for the nuts to aid in mounting.
  • Beveled sharp edges so it wasn't so deadly :)
  • Adjusted tolerances so it fits like a glove and mounts better.

This is my first re-mix. Fully tested by me and I love it.

Monoprice Maker Select v2.1

35%

comments.text: Hard to tell from the picture but looks like your phone is almost horizontal or parallel to the ground.  How secure does this hold your phone?  Would it be as secure if the phone/mount is rotated so it's vertical or perpendicular to the ground?
comments.author: ampster

comments.text: I am using this and I can tell you it is sturdy and the phone is clipped in. It has to be unclipped to come out. If there were to be a failure it wouldn't be from sliding out. It would have to be from a clip failure due to some insane bump (which I just don't see happening) and it makes sense to me that would most likely occur with the phone being horizontal or parallel to the ground and not vertical or perpendicular to the ground (unless of course you had some kind of massive front impact). I actually have my holder tilted forward as far as the RAM Mount will go. I would say it is more horizontal than vertical. I am feeling quite good about how well it holds and I don't worry about it coming out at any point during the ride. You could modify the design further if you wanted to ease your mind by adding hooks on both side edges of the phone or I could do that for you. Let me know.
comments.author: ampster

comments.text: Thank You for the quick reply.  I've modified the model some in Fusion 360 so that it allows the case to remain on the Galaxy S7 Edge.
comments.author: Bryson_Jack

comments.text: Good deal. Hope it works well for you. I re-designed/tweaked it to work with just the device and no case so I can see why you need to modify it.
comments.author: ampster

comments.text: Thanks.  The reason I wanted to leave the case on was when assembled the screws from the RAM mount were right on the surface of the phone.  Didn't want to scratch it!
comments.author: Bryson_Jack

comments.text: The screws are sunk in so they can't scratch your phone (at least on the one that I printed). I checked the back of my phone and there is absolutely no scratch anywhere from using it. There probably aren't many people that take better care of their stuff than me and I wouldn't be using it if there was the slightest chance of doing any damage to my phone. If it is a case of your bolts being too long, you could always use washers as spacers or put the screw head in the nut area and the bolt on the underside.
comments.author: ampster

comments.text: bah - gave up on using 645 nylon.  I've got to figure out how to reduce warping.  Ended up using alloy 910 and the very first set of clips turned out perfect.  tight fit all around.  The case is a "Speck" brand.  If it holds up during the trip I'll post the files towards the end of next week.  A little concerned with alloy 910 as it can be brittle but should hold up OK.
comments.author: Bryson_Jack

comments.text: 645 nylon seems to shrink more so than other filaments.  Everything was pretty much a tight fit and the screws/locknuts stuck out a bit.  I've added 2mm thickness to the clips where the screws go thru and sunk the hex holes deeper by 1mm.  645 nylon also warps more than I'd like, compared to alloy 910.  The outside corners were warping so I beefed up those areas hoping to spread the heat out a bit and am printing on rafts with full height skirts to minimize the warping.  Will post results when I'm happy with the outcome.  Thanks for the stl files and design!
comments.author: Bryson_Jack

description.text:
Multi-Purpose Handle

It's not just a handle, but greatly improves the accessibility of your printer. It's comfortable and keeps you from having to touch the heated bed directly.

This was originally designed with the intent of mounting a webcam to move along with the bed while capturing time-lapse build videos via Octoprint. I have tried to design this to be fairly universal for mounting cameras, lights, and other accessories you might need.

Features:
  • Wiring channel routes wires discreetly along the inside of the handle and out of sight
  • Quick release set pins - change or remove handles easily
  • Various mounting points - Selectable mounting positions

author: CreationStationBCL

title: Anet A8 Front brace with kill switch bracket

description.text:
I wanted to add a way to shut the printer down when the print was over. The way the A8 is setup, we cannot use Gcode alone to do this. I asked around on the net and was sent a video from someone that was using a switch to kill the printer at the end of a print. I used this idea and adapted it to my printer. All you need to do is add some Gcode to the end print section in CURA to move the bed forward in order to trigger the switch. This is what mine looks like.

Je voulais une façon de pouvoir éteindre mon imprimante une fois l'impresion terminée. Il n'est malheureusement pas possible de le faire seulement avec les Gcode pour le A8 d'Anet. J'ai fouillé sur l'internet et quelqu'un m'a montré un vidéo d'une personne qui utilisait un interrupteur pour éteindre l'imprimante. Je suis parti de ce concept et je l'ai adapté à ma configuration. Maintenant, il suffit de modifier le Gcode de fin d'impression dans CURA pour faire avancer le lit et activer l'interrupteur. Voici ma configuration.

M104 S0 ;extruder heater off
M140 S0 ;heated bed heater off (if you have it)
G91 ;relative positioning
G1 E-1 F300 ;retract the filament a bit before lifting the nozzle, to release some of the pressure
G1 Z+0.5 E-5 X-20 Y-20 F(travel_speed) ;move Z up a bit and retract filament even more
G28 X0 Y0 ;move X/Y to min endstops, so the head is out of the way
G4 P120000 ;
G0 Y215
M84 ;steppers off
G90 ;absolute positioning

Anet A8

No support needed

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ns7LYfCwamQ" ></iframe>
Switch in action, Interrupteur en action

comments.text: With a raspberry pi running OctoPrint and a relay you can achieve the same. Just add a custom gcode command (OctoPrint plugin) to the end code section in OctoPrint (e.g. OCTO 100, and define that this code runs the printer_off.sh shell script). No need for a switch.

author: cyberew2000

title: 3D Printable Jet Engine parts for 120x120x120 Build Plate and Skate Bearings

description.text: I wanted to print the awesome "3D Printable Jet Engine" model on my Monoprice Select Mini and also wanted to use readily available skate bearings. To print on the mini, scale all parts from the original model to 55%. The files included here are scaled to 55% and adapted to accept skate bearings as the four bearings needed in the model. The HPC Spool shafts are reduced to fit through the middle of skate bearings and the HPT and HPC Spool are modified to fit a skate bearing. I did not modify the fan stator casing and support or nozzle but rather made the included shim so that a skate bearing fits into them when those original files are printed at 55%.

title: Stand for Mini LED Flashlight with Gimbal Clamp

description.text:
I needed an LED flashlight holder and "Stand for Mini LED Flashlight by Smidge204" is one of the designs that I printed. Just looking at the original design, I couldn't conceive of how it wouldn't just fall over from the weight of the flashlight after a few uses. Well I was correct. That is exactly what happens. I made the gimbal with a lock so that particular problem is no longer an issue. The flashlight stand is not very tall, but if you want something pretty low to the surface, it is a decent stand.

I used 1 bolt and 1 wingnut for assembly. Specifically I used (1) #6-32 Stainless Steel Standard (SAE) Forged Wing Nut and (1) #6-32 x 3/4 inch bolt, both by Hillman, from Lowes. Thread the bolt into the smaller hole on the Gimbal Lock first.

description.text: Here is my inexpensive way to get an Micro SD slot connected to the Ultimaker.  The UltiController would cost me close to $200 including shipping to get.  Plus, I don't really need the display screen that comes with it.

I got this board on ebay: http://www.ebay.com/itm/260974675033?ssPageName=STRK:MEWNX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1439.l2649#ht_1002wt_714 The side of Micro SD board with the slot has the pins labelled. However, there are names and extra pins like DO, D1, D2, CD etc. that wasn't matching with the names for the pins on EXP2 on the Ultimaker board: http://www.reprap.org/wiki/Ultimaker%27s_v1.5.3_PCB Looking on the other side of the Micro SD board that has "WAVESHARE" shows labels to the pins closely matching to the EXP2 on the UM board. I use only those pins to connect to the UM board EXP2. The other pins are not even labelled on this side of the board and are not used. Here are the connections. Again, look at the "WaveShare" side of the Micro SD board: Micro SD pins ---> EXP2 UM pins 3.3V ---> 3.3V GND ---> GND MISO(DO) ---> MISO MOSI(DI) ---> MOSI SCLK ---> SCK CS ---> SS The ribbon cable is a grey 10 wire IDC cable pressed connected to an IDC female plug. Assembly of the plug/wire is on Makerbot support. The other end of the cable is soldered to individual female plugs. I got the female plugs at Fry's Electronics and I don't see them in stock anymore. This is a work in progress because I haven't printed anything from this card yet. So far I am able to see gcode files from the small 4GB card in Printrun. If your computer doesn't have a Micro SD slot then an Adapter card like the one on the right is needed to insert to a regular size SD slot. The blank.txt file was just added to meet the requirement of having something that was not an image uploaded.

comments.text: One other thing for clarification. The pin labels on the side with the slot are for a different type of interface. There is multiple ways to use these boards and a couple different interface types. The ones you are using are for the SPI interface which uses fewer lines and is what should interface to your controller.

description.text: This is a spool holder for the top of robo printer or can be use on flat surface. You need to print 2 of the bases and 4 wheels. I printed on side with no supports were needed.

The pieces for this zhanchi are extremely small, and I would recommend that you scale each file up before printing by about 10x (If you decide to print the torpedoes, I have no clue what to scale it up to). This will make the pieces similar in size to the original, and it would probably be close enough that you could use hardware from other cubes. if it is too small, try smaller hardware, and if it is too big, try bigger hardware.
You will need to print:
1 Core
6 Center pieces
6 Center caps
24 Edge pieces
24 Corner pieces
12 Torpedoes (Optional)

description.text:
This is a stepped holder to lift the back of your dish drying rack so the water drains into the sink.

I created this because the sink in the break room where I work has a lip which causes the rack to tip away from the sink and the counter is always wet. This way it drains directly into the sink.

I didn't know how high to lift the rack, so I made it stepped - the steps are at 10mm increments. Happy accident it looks vaguely like a wave.

It's a very rough design, clearly, but it works pretty well. Very well actually.

Added a version 2. It has roundovers on the front and rear edges. I noticed the first one chipped on the back edge, and could pinch a finger on the front edge (comments from people at work). Printed v2 with no supports, curves came out fine.

title: Viking Hut (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This Viking hut is designed for OpenTactics, our new modular 3D-print-and-play miniatures boardgame (though you can really use it with pretty much any wargame or RPG you like). You can fine these and our other terrain sets in this growing collection.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like OpenTactics, Pocket-Tactics, Discord, and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

remixed_from.title: OctoPrint Raspberry Pi Rig 3.5" PiTFT Touch Display

title: OctoPrint PiTFT Stand w/ Raspberry Pi Logo

description.text:
I decided to put together a PiTFT Octoprint server, and rather than print a plain stand, I decided to customize it with the Raspberry Pi logo. It's in the back, so you can't see it that well, but I know it's there!

I printed this without supports by printing with the logo face down. The arms cantilevered out at a steep enough angle to print successfully. The surface finish on the face that holds the Pi was a little rough, since it basically printed upside down, but you can't see it anyway.

Timelapse of Print (11h40m)
https://youtu.be/-XaNjE_4_J0

Printer:

Originial Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.100mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Sliced in Cura 2.4.0

How I modified the STL file (general purpose instructions for modifying an STL in F360)
  1. Imported the STL file for the base into Fusion360 as a Mesh.
  2. Right-clicked on the top level and clicked "turn off design history".
  3. Right click on the mesh and select "convert to BRep".
  4. Construct Plane through 2 edges (pick edges of diagonal face)
  5. Create sketch on that plane
  6. Import SVG RPi logo
  7. Extrude through the body leaving negative
  8. I also selected the outline of the SVG, created an offset and extruded that halfway through to get a nice outline for the logo.
  9. Re-export as STL, slice, and print.

I bought some Filaments.ca spools, so I had to modify my endcaps for the bore of those spools.
There are two files here, because the rim of the bore in Filaments.ca filament spools have a wider tolerance than others, so if the cap-filmaentsca is just a little too small, you can try the cap-filamentsca_largerside.
So far, I've found this size works for the "Standard PLA" spools, both the 1kg and 2kg varieties.

The SCAD file requires the partial rotate extrude, which I linked to as a "remix".

There's never a convenient spot to sneak a can of your favorite libation when riding a Ducati. If you have the good fortune of removing the original riser bars (and use an aftermarket handlebar system), then you can use that old handlebar mount to affix this thing to your bike and... voila! Instant on-the-road beverage.

The T-shaped doo-hickies at the base allow you to use a rubber band to secure your can or boba tea when jumping over speed bumps and whatnot. Thread one (or two) rubber band(s) through the linkage and loop them around the doo-hickies at the bottom.

Oh yeah - don't drink and drive/ride. :)

If you found this useful, it would bring me great joy to see your work - so be sure to share. :)

Also, feel free to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

This is a sliding lid box for holding 50 rounds of 22WMR rimfire ammo, similar to my previous 100 round 22LR Bullet Holder.

No special instructions other than using a 0.2500" reamer (preferred) or a 1/4" drill bit (works as well, just not as smooth) chucked up in a drill to clean up the holes in the bullet trays, then using 220 grit sandpaper to smooth out the sides and edges before using them.

I like to print the box in bright neon colors, and the lids in either transparent clear or transparent black. The trays I have printed both ways, and it really depends on what is in the printer as to whether they get the lid color or the box color.

author: wilper21

description.text:
This is an adapter that snaps onto the knee steering column of a Segway Minipro and allows for the addition of a 7/8" wooden dowel or aluminum tube type T handle into a properly angled socket which contains screw or rivet holes to attach the extension with. Although it is snug snap fit onto the steering column, you must add a worm screw type hose clamp to keep it snugly attached. When inserting the dowel or tube, cut the protruding end that extends through the adapter to be flush with the flat surface. This provides both more dowel support as well as preventing twisting. Use at your own risk.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/hISNYKFdueJ

title: Spool holder for mp select mini

description.text: I bought this damaged Mp select mini at a garage sell for 20 dollars and when I bought it it was missing the spool holder, the LCD screen, and the button controller. While searching for a replacement for the spool holder I couldn't find anything that could print quickly and one that will for my 120x120 print bed. If You Have a drill you Can drill directly into the black side piece if not you can use the bracket that is also in the file the bracket fits into the existing mount for the original spool holder. I'll also have other prints for this printer. This spool holder will fit any filament roll with a 50mm hole in the center.

description.text: A custom spinner for use (designed for speed)

This is a filament guide for the Makerbot 2x. It connects to the back of the printer where you clip in the filament tube. This guide will help keep the tube in place so it doesn't fall out of it's place.
first post not exactly sure how big it is

I've been playing (the amazingly awesome) Banner Saga, and I felt inspired to make a 28mm version of a Varl (the race of giants featured in the game). For those interested in a deep, beautifully animated turn-based tactics game, check The Banner Saga out. The single player campaign is available on Steam, and the multi-player only version, Banner Saga Tactics, is available for free. http://stoicstudio.com/
Printed mine at a .10 layer height at 10% infill.

comments.text: I can't find any mention of a multiplayer version on their website (and I've been playing the single player since it came out!).
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Oh, I just found this! There's a free-to-play multiplayer version on Steam called Banner Saga Factions. Its been up for a little over a year now, apparently. Some friends and I just played it.

Inspiring as always bro.  I just downloaded sculptris and started watching tutorial.  Zbrush was a bit much to fast.  I like the way sculptris creates divisions in the mesh automatically to create smooth contours and then you can reduce with another tool.  The Global Game Jam is this weekend and I will have a printer there with me and be modeling for the first time and printing all the parts complete to have a newly developed and playable game after only 48 hrs.  That would be easy for you heck you will probably design two in your sleep next weekend(: lol nice work again.  We need to team up on a Game Jam next year.  There 2 Alumni from my school that come down to our campus from Washington to participate.

description.text: This is a fidget spinner I designed specifically to look like the very popular ones, but in a 3d printed form! The bearing holes are slightly larger than normal, so a bearing should either fit perfectly or might require some glue. It all depends on your 3d printer!

This is another testing piece.  A standard 10mm x 10mm x 10mm cube that will test the your two colour printing ability.  Use this part for testing the offset values and checking your nozzle wipe.  You may also find differences between the two colours of PLA or ABS or your two nozzles.
Print, Adjust, Learn.

Files:
0024a.stl is the combined shape, a 10mmx10mmx10mm cube
0024b.stl is for colour one
0024c.stl is for colour two
  • Write down the settings you used to build the G Code
  • Print and mark with letter to note print settings
  • Record print time, surface finish, weight and how close it is to 10mm in all directions
  • Print again to determine your printers precision/repeatability.
    • Its just good to keep track of these things. Its SCIENCE!

This base was designed for a glass dome of 140mm in dia. and 11" tall. It was created using Tinkercad and printed on the i3x Geeetech Prusa. .2 layer height with a 10% infill. I tried to cut the print time down by making two processes in Simplified 3D but it did significantly reduce the print time of 13hr. So I just left it at 10% infill throughout. I used PETG blk from Inland brand. It has a nice shinny surface and almost looks acrylic. 3 top layers covers the 10% infill nicely.

author: wilper21

remixed_from.author: brianvanh
remixed_from.title: Z Adjustable Bed for K40 Chinese Laser

description.text:
This is my first remix design. I reworked the original in Fusion 360 to give me a more rigid design. The top of the bed cannot bend inward due to the upper frame and nuts holding it to the threaded rod posts. Adjustments are easily done with a screwdriver. Hopefully the pictures/video make sense. Please refer to the original design by brianvanh for more details on exactly how it goes together, but it should be pretty clear from the photos I took as well. Here is a video of the bed in "action" https://youtu.be/lJH4dM1vxqo

In the video, I have not yet updated to the square tubing frame. You may be able to see the "flexing" I experienced with the aluminum angle. Please refer to the pictures for details.

TENSIONER:
I added a belt tensioner as I had issues with belt tension. You can see in the pictures that the tensioner is a simple pulley bolted into a slot made in a small piece of aluminum flat. The tensioner is riveted to the lower frame. the tensioner pulley can move freely up/down the bolt it is on and will not come off. Here is the kit I bought that had all the little parts I needed for the tensioner (if the link doesn't work, search ebay for "8Pcs-GT2-20T-Bore-8mm-Timing-Pulley-5m-Belt-Tensioner-For-RepRap-3D-Printer"):

http://www.ebay.com/itm/8Pcs-GT2-20T-Bore-8mm-Timing-Pulley-5m-Belt-Tensioner-For-RepRap-3D-Printer-/292098299234?hash=item44026a5562:g:87gAAOSwtZJZAVJG

FRAME:
I changed the frame from an aluminum angle to a steel square tube. IMO, this is a must do. The aluminum angle is just a little to flexible for me. With the square tubing, the frame is rock solid (as much as it can be anyway :-). ALSO, in my pictures, the top frame is aluminum angle, but I switched to square tubing to eliminate all flexing and give the top bed a little more weight so it "sits" on the nuts that travel up/down the threaded rods a little better. Too light, and the bed may slip off of the nuts. I did not glue my corner brackets to the nuts because I wanted it to be removable. I have not had any issues.

THREADED ROD/BEARING:
Note the route I took to secure the bearings in my design. I needed a way to get the bearings tight on the rod, so I used extra nuts. The nuts do not get in the way of the bed operation. ALSO NOTE: I just used a Dremel and cut a slot in the top of one of the threaded rods and use a screwdriver to adjust the bed height. It is almost too easy!

All of the other dimensions are in the original design. You may have to adjust the length of your square tubing by a tad in order to get the bed to fit right. This bed was a TIGHT fit in my machine, but it works great.

SECURING BED TO MACHINE:
I took the extra time to bolt the bed to my laser. I just marked for one hole in the front and back bottom square tubing pieces and drilled a hole in each. Then I moved the bed without the top to the laser, marked where the holes were to line up on the bottom of the laser and drilled them out. Then I just used two bolts with wing nuts to secure the bed in place. This keeps the bed from moving around and keeps your bed from moving after you aligned your work on the laser bed.

EXPANDED MESH:
I just used some tape to secure the mesh bed to the top square tubing frame. It has not failed and keeps it pretty secure. I did use super glue initially and later had to remove the bed.... Well, I almost broke my corner brackets and bent the mesh bed trying to pry them apart. Hence the tape I use now.

BELT:
OK, I could not find a solid solution to securing the belt together to make one continuous loop. I ended up cutting a small strip of belt and cutting the teeth off of it to make it thinner. Then I grabbed the two ends of my belt that is going in the machine and matched the teeth up with another small piece of belt so the teeth will mesh fine with the pulleys. Once you do that, grab your stripped down piece of belt and apply a small amount of super glue and stick it on the back side of the belt that is going in your machine. Once you do that, then stick it in a vice or something to clamp it down while the glue dries. Don't apply too much pressure as this will make the belt squish out and once it dries, the teeth will not mesh well with the pulleys (don't ask...). Also, don't tension the belt too tight once you have it in your machine. If you use my method of securing your belt together, there will be a small section that is slightly thicker due to the added belt to hold the two ends together. That piece will go over the tensioner pulley and add a bit more tension due to the added thickness of the belt where it is glued together.

FEELING FROGGY?
If regular threaded rod isn't good enough, get yourself some ACME threaded rod or similar and use ACME threaded nuts instead of the nuts I used on the threaded rod. Of course, you will have to modify the STL's...

comments.author: peddiparth

comments.text: I have been using this bed since I made it and the belt has been fine.  I have cut many things on it, and sometimes overlapping the belt below.  Maybe I have been lucky, but I do see the concern.  There are no visible signs of my belt being damaged by the laser as of today.  A simple guard over the belt by the tensioner should alleviate any potential issues.

comments.text: You can get 'closed' GT2 belts to avoid having to join them.  You can get long ones (even up to 3 metres!) but around 1100-1300mm will work for this.

description.text:
I beat my poor Arrma pretty well and it spends a lot of time sliding on its roof. Decided to save a few bucks and model this part. I tried to print this three different ways on the initial print, to see what worked best. The picture with four is what seems to have given the best result.

I made them for my Outcast, but believe you may be able to use them with the Kraton as well. Happy printing.

title: CubeX Part Cooling Fan - Front Mounted

description.text:
This is a part cooling fan for the CubeX and possibly Cube Pro 3D (not verified) printers. It uses a centrifugal blower (see specs below). The blower spacing is for using extruders 1 and 3. Remember to print two ducts. I will eventually upload a plenum for a 1-2, 2-3, and 1-2-3 option. Constructive feedback is appreciated.

These files are a work in progress. I prefer to have all my parts snap together without fasteners, but the plenum will need to be glued in place for now until I finalize the design.

Fan

Delta Electronics

BFB0512H-R00 (12V)
https://www.digikey.com/products/en?keywords=BFB0512H-R00

BFB0524H-R00 (24V)
https://www.digikey.com/products/en?keywords=BFB0524H-R00

Flow: 3.9cfm @0.709in H20
Noise: 38dB
Size: 51mm x 51.3mm x 15mm

Hardware

Socket Head Machine Screws M3 x 0.5 mm, 6 mm Long (quantity 2)
https://www.mcmaster.com/#91292a111/=17i1kxt

Glue

Loctite Professional Liquid Super Glue
http://www.loctiteproducts.com/p/sg_bottle_pro/overview/Loctite-Super-Glue-Liquid-Professional.htm

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Use PETG or ABS.

The models print easily with no supports.

The ducts require a raft so that they don't get knocked over. If you flip them around the other way, the overhang is too extreme for PETG (on my printer at least).

Assembly

1) Clean prints of stringing, blogs, and check internals for blockage.
2) Glue the plenum to the bracket with super glue. I use tape to align and secure it until the glue dries.
3) Snap in the two ducts.The ducts snap into place as long as your printer is well calibrated.
4) Screw the assembly onto the front of the carriage using the two outside screw holes where the OEM fan attaches.
5) Slide in the fan wires through the slot and snap fan into place. The blue wire is not used.
6) Connect power to your preferred source on your control board, or build a fused circuit directly from the power supply. Make sure you get the correct voltage fan for your 3d printer.

description.text:
THREE, TWO, ONE, GOOOOOOOO!!!! Three years later, the definite version of Mario Kart 8 has arrived to the Switch . To celebrate this event, I have made a custom Standard Kart (on Anti-Gravity mode) to represent the box art of the game. I based on the mario maker sprite form, which is awesome. If you want to add this kart to your collection, please download the file to custom print your own. If you have feedback, please reply to me in the comments. I hope you guys enjoy and like this print and the next upcoming projects.

Credits: To Spriters resource, Nintendo, and their fans everywhere.

Note: I should probably mention that this is prototype for my one of my upcoming design

P.s. I sorry for the delay in uploads, I had to study for exams this week but thankfully it is over. P.s.s I making a more customizable kart, so instead of printing one whole model you can print and build it muti-colored versions. ... And yes, it have an attachable gilder plus the underwater propeller.
P.s.s.s : Also I have a trip next week so my design schedule is iffy. Thank Life.

Just a set of files cut from other designs that you can combine together for a fidget toy. Have one cylinder and two spacers or 3 cylinders and two spacers or two bolts like in the picture - several combos that work. All credit for designs go to original designers - I just combined them and made a slight modification to one.

I was printing the gun cylinder pen holder and realized that it would not be large enough for the type of pen i was using it for. I cancelled the print leaving the height at about what is in the .stl file included.

Later I was doing homework and had absentmindedly placed it on the bearing press nut and bolt. I fidgeted with it for quite a while and thought maybe others would like to as well. So I did some trial and error plane cuts and ended up with this.

All credit should go to the original designers - I just mixed it up.

author: devin1234

print_settings.Notes:: Also, be aware of sharp edges, corners, etc.

title: Impossible Dovetail Puzzle Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As seen on Chinese wholesalers, this is a replica of the impossible dovetail puzzle box. It is ingeniously simple in design, but it can boggle an experienced puzzler's mind for a stretch.

Fair warning: there are sharp points and edges, and the tolerances for the ball bearing might require you to hone out the holes a bit.

If you remake this, for attribution please simply note that it was inspired by the wooden puzzle boxes found around online.

Note: TWO magnets are REQUIRED for this to work properly! Also one ferrous 3/8" (9mm) steel ball bearing. If you use a 10mm version, enlarge both holes appropriately.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini v1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2625

Infill:

15%

Notes:

4mm thick shells/walls or larger. This gets hit a LOT with sharp strikes!

Also, be aware of sharp edges, corners, etc.

8mm Neodymium magnets or smaller + 9mm or 3/8" steel ball

Before you start, check the ball to see if it moves freely in the top hole. Hone out the hole as needed.

Use two identical magnets, with the same pole facing each other, using polyurethane or acrylic glue. The steel ball must jump from the bottom magnet to the top magnet to unlock the box, which requires a sharps strike.

comments.text: I used to have a couple of these made from wood.  Broke both from slapping it on the table so much - broke along the grain each time.  Wondering if this is any more durable.
comments.author: drbanks

comments.text: why two magnets? Wouldn't it just stick to one side if it has two?
comments.author: FcasCreator

comments.text: That's actually the point.  The ball needs to jump from the locking magnet to the unlock magnet. Otherwise, the metal ball will bounce back to the locking magnet; the unlock magnet captures the ball, allowing the user to open the case.  If there were only an unlock magnet, the ball simply would stick to it and render the puzzle unlocked.
comments.author: FcasCreator

comments.text: Alternatively, if you put just the locking magnet in, it would make the puzzle harder (you'd have to apply just enough pressure along the dovetail while hitting it to make it unlock). It'd be easy to lose the ball bearing upon solving it though.
comments.author: RWReese

comments.text: Unfortunately, that won't work.  The space between the two planes when pressure is applied to the ball is physically too narrow for the ball to pass through.  The pressure can only be applied when the ball's centerline is above the split plane, and the only time that occurs is during the ball's travel immediately after striking it.  However, the travel path is so short, and the ball's velocity is so great, it would be nearly impossible to accomplish trapping the ball above the split: the round-trip travel time, since the ball bounces off the plastic on top, is merely hundredths of a second, means it's impossible for a person to do this intentionally and only shear luck (pun, not typo) would get it open.
comments.author: vgf89

author: sabharish

title: Zombie Apocalypse - A new take on an old game.

description.text: This is an update of a very old two player game known variously as Hare and Hounds, the French Military Game and several other names. There's more information on the pieces at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:229413 and on the game itself at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hare_and_Hounds_(board_game) I first came across hare and hounds when reading through Martin Gardner's Mathematical Games column in an old copy of Scientific American. If you play it you'll find there's a lot more strategy to it than first meets the eye. Try an on-line version here : http://www.mazeworks.com/hounds/ I've also done a full write-up on Instructables : http://www.instructables.com/id/Zombie-Apocalypse-A-Simple-Board-Game/

The object of the game for the Human is to to try to escape to the far end of the board.
The aim for the Zombies is to surround the human so he can't move. The starting position is shown in the 3rd picture. The Zombies move first and can only move one space forwards (including diagonally) or sideways along the pathways - Never backwards. The Human can move one space in any direction along the paths. If a set of moves is continually repeated the Zombies tire and the Human escapes. Alternatively, you could use the middle of the board for simple 3x3 noughts and crosses (tic-tac-toe) type games, or make a lot of the game-pieces and leave them to be found, just to baffle people. (This game could be played on a board drawn on a piece of paper and four counters, but heyyyy . . . I've got a 3-D printer ;-)

comments.text: Beautiful game, I made one and added some figures, thanks!

author: Hypnoron

description.text:
Note: Currently this thing doesn't render in Customizer. You will need to use the OpenSCAD to customize and render until I fix that.

Inspired by Tigeer's Cargo bushing block I created a customizable SC8UU-sized mounting block for bushings. It's intended to be a direct replacement for commonly used SC8UU mounting block with LM8UU linear bearing and has the following advantages:

  • Aligns to the rod axis;
  • Less play (this depends on exact rod diameter and the bushing You choose);
  • Less weight -- around 15g for the bronze bushing + mounting block + nuts vs. 56g for SC8UU (including LM8UU);
  • Much quieter;
  • Integrated oiling.

There are two types of the bushing clamp, both of which allow aligning bushing to the rod before tightening to prevent jamming. First is the torus shaped clamp, second is the clamp with the rubber ring inspired by mataor's and MaxEkb77's implementations. See sectioned view pictures.

For the rubber ring clamps I used pieces of 1.75mm rubber filament. Also any suitable rubber ring can be used (You can cut it if needed), it's diameter can be adjusted in Customizer. I found rubber ring clamp to perform a little better, but much harder to assemble.

It also has the space for the oiling block, so You can use some felt or foamy material soaked with light oil grease (like machine oil or motor oil) to feed the oil to the rod. Correction: low viscosity grease seem to increase stick-slip effect, high viscosity grease (or no grease) should perform better here. Thanks again to mataor for the idea.

I tested mounting blocks with HC-Cargo 140947 and 140916 bronze bushings and included STLs for them. There are also definitions for other common bushings and You can enter sizes of any suitable bushing in Customizer (or directly in OpenSCAD).

Common sources of bushings:

  • Many bronze bushings from HC-Cargo catalog and IKA catalog should be available in local car parts stores.
  • JDB graphite filled self-lubricating brass bushings available from Aliexpress.
  • SF-1 PTFE-coated self-lubricating bushings from Aliexpress.

This is a work in progress. The OpenSCAD code is quite ugly and needs to be simplified. Comments and suggestions are welcome.

comments.text:
Ever heard about press fitting and self taping screws ?
6 screws should be enough to fix everything ! On my design I don't have any screw for the X, bushings (my own) integrated in the carriage.
That is cost (parts and time) and weight saving !
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I need to have the carriage modular and want to disassemble/reassemble and tune it quickly instead of reprinting the whole thing, or breaking it with self-tapping screws. So here it is. Nuts and bolts weight around 30g, I think, which is nothing compared to the 300g motor. I will evaluate your suggestion, thanks!
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
You need half as much screws and self-tapping won't crack PETG. Just have the right sized hole. I use inserts or nuts only when I need to dismount often.
Press fit the bushings in a longer housing when possible (I did it for m X) and align using a heat gun (I did this for my Y) for bronze bushings or a reamer for Igus (they have to be made undersized of course).
Or use autoalign bushings (I use two fixed on one rod and for the other, one autoalign).
30g for me is more than 10% gain as my current X carriage+extruder etc... is about 270g. 240g if I use a pancake motor.
comments.author: frol

comments.text: PETG is nice but costs 3 times more than ABS here, forget about Igus filament.

This is an hourglass sand timer printed with natural translucent PLA for the "glass" which completely encloses the sand.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KmxJaU5Fkpk&feature=youtu.be There are two versions of the glass; one with a narrower neck and the other wider. I used sand from a craft store, which isn't very fine, so I used the wider hourglass for the version you see in the video.
If you can find really fine sand, then try the narrow version. Your time will vary depending on the size you print and the type of sand you use. It turns out that in one direction the time is consistently 9 seconds and the other it is 12. It must be due to the texture of the print.

This thing was made on a MakerBot Replicator 2 using PLA.
Natural translucent PLA was used for the hourglass part.
You will need to print it with 1 shell and 0% infill.
Standard resolution seems to work the best.
The version you see in the pictures and video was scaled to 200%. The critical step in this build is filling the enclosed glass with sand.
To do this, cold pause (sleep) the print of the hourglass at about 95% (you should also hear the tone of the printer change the last couple of layers before the top).
When paused, carefully pour a measured amount of sand into the glass, then resume the print.
You might want to do a dry run or two to get the amount right and to make sure that the sand you're using flows nicely through the neck.
